I believe Valery is referring to the Community Reinvestment Act which was passed in 1977 under Carter. it is a common place conservatives point to when they want to deny that the architects of the crisis were Phil Gramm, Alan Greenspan and Wall Street. It is simply an anti-redlining bill that requires banks to use the same lending standards in all areas they cover. No banks has ever been forced to give a loan that does not meet its lending standards under the CRA.

But as Paul Krugman had pointed out, the killer is that the CRA only applies to federally charted banks which gave out less than 2% of the subprime and alt A loans. Most were supplied by mortgage companies like New Century to be bundled into CDO's by Wall Street,

This is another Zombie idea,

Bottom line:

American Enterprise Institute has nothing to teach us. If it emanates from their people, it is biased and partisan.

Have I correctly expressed the sentiment, setting aside the fact that Fannie and Freddie control the standards for the overwhelming number of American mortgages, are an agency of the the US government, are heavily involved with the political class in Washington, are not truly subject to the scrutiny found in "take and hold" or "balance sheet" mortgages, and who have set the down payment levels at incredibly leveraged points…to encourage home purchases among the least capable of meeting the obligation?

Other than that, we have nothing to learn from the American Enterprise Institute and this very legitimate analysis of another bubble.

The fact that the market is exceeding levels seen just a handful of years ago does not require a degree from MIT to know we are probably inflating prices, again.

Len Charlap is correct about the CRA. The CRA requires banks to extend credit throughout their service areas *consistent with good underwriting practices.* The CRA was not enacted to encourage subprime lending. Quite the contrary: it was enacted to expand prime lending that had been constrained by redlining, as Len points out.

"Both this bubble and the last one were caused by the government’s housing policies"

No, they weren't. The last bubble was caused by loose lending standards. That was precipitated by the finance industry's use of cdo's to disconnect the risk created by bad loans from the makers of those loans. In fact, bad loans had a substantial market value.

Part of that problem could be laid on the low interest paid on AAA US Treasuries. Bond and mutual funds, whose prospectus promised AAA quality bonds, needed something that would create better returns. AAA rated bonds backed by real estate provided that product.

In short, the last bubble was a creative invention of smart people in the finance industry who profited enormously from it.

There has always been a disconnect between the housing market and the rental market. It is nothing new. They are only rigidly connected in ideological economic theories. Obviously the cost of real estate is one of the factors in determining rent, but there are a lot of others as well.

Professor Krugman -- you'll figure this one out if you look at the distribution of wealth.

The problem is that the Federal Reserve can basically only give "cheap loans" or "cheap money" to *RICH PEOPLE*. By doing so, it's creating bubbles. We need to give "cheap money" to *POOR PEOPLE*, which is what the economy needs, but the Federal Reserve is structured so that it simply can't do that, not really...

This is why FDR founded a bunch of federally-run banks which lent directly to individuals and small businesses.

Andrea E, you raise a valid point.

However, to do so while ignoring the legitimate observations of others -- how the fright-wing has used the phrase as a cudgel, insinuating that the less fortunate are personally, independently, totally responsible for their plight -- reduces your comment to little more than a Teapublican talking point.

Andrea E,
The point you are missing is that Republicans have, for decades been using "personal responsibility" to blame the poor for the situation they are in without any regard for the other causes of poverty. In other words they attack the poor by saying they aren't personally responsible for themselves which perpetuates the myth that the poor are lazy and don't want to work.

So those attacking the "personal responsibility" argument are are really attacking a group that claims the poor are the ones to blame for being poor.

@DC, Stephen, Ken.

Personal responsibility does play a role, and so do structural problems.

While you complain that the right uses it as a cudgel against the poor to blame them for their troubles, others can say that the left uses structural poverty and racism as a shield against any reasonable suggestion that poor people have to make some effort on behalf of themselves and their children if any program is actually going to work.

The left's view of the poor, that their poverty prevents them from being thinking humans with agency and individual motivations is paternalistic and classist. Many people simply aren't motivated towards the goal of getting out of poverty, it's not a priority, and they are unwilling to put forth the effort of learning to read and do math, or use birth control, or any number of tiny easy free things they can do double and triple their odds of getting out of poverty.

The left's denial of this reality, which most people have observed first hand at some point in people close to them, is disingenuous.

More claptrap from the Calvanist right wing think tank. What does he mean by "Personal Responsibility?"

When you are barely making enough to just get by, scrimping on everything you can, that is about as responsible as you can get. Those in the low income brackets, or on some sort of public assistance, would not be there if they had the intellectual ability to escape.

The great majority of these people do not spend time philosophizing, or reading the journal of Abnormal Psychology, most of them do not even understand checkbook balancing. Intervention is needed to see that their kids get good meals, and a basic education at the minimum. Forget all the modern educators grandiose ideas, they need to be able to read, write, do ordinary math, and understand what they read..

I once knew a prison councilor who told me that over 70% of the inmates were illiterate. You will not bring up the skills of those who have been poor for long periods, but you need programs that keep their kids in schools and make them want to be there.

It is in our own interests to see that the impoverished are given the ability to get out of poverty, and history has shown us, most of them can not do it without help. There are always exceptions, but anecdotal examples are not the norm, as these conservative "Think Tanks" would have you believe. They want yo to think people like living that way, with no scientific evidence to show such, just their inflated opinions.

'...My parents' generation, educated in the fifties and sixties, was a very successful one...'

The WWII and Korean War generations had good jobs because only white men need apply. Women and people of any other color need not apply for any job that did not require a broom.

That generation of white males congratulates themselves for all their hard work, but the truth is that most of those men would be unemployable in the economy of the past three decades.

They never faced any real competition and now that the younger generations have supported them in their decades of retirement, for which they contributed pennies on the dollar, if anything, they continue to be ungrateful for what was, in essence, handed to them on a silver platter.
So unsurprised to hear from this source that "Head start", whose positive effects on academic performance disappear after 1st grade, works "like it was intended to".  Sure is easy to type.

After the second world war, that ended in 1945, the only industrial country that was NOT in ruin was the US. So, your parents generation had the unique opportunity to have a decent, middle class wage for eight hours of honest work. Any work. Today that is gone, pfft... If you do eight hours of honest work, you get the wages of the golden arches or of an illegal immigrant.

Head start, the job corps, the higher education act, and the other measures that were implemented did the job they were intended to do. My parents' generation, educated in the fifties and sixties, was a very successful one. It isn't until the Reagan years that the educational gap widened, in direct correlation to cuts to entitlements and investment in education, health, etc.

Improving our existing programs without greatly expanding their funding is preposterous. Head Start funding, for example, is insufficient. President Obama's proposal to make Pre-K on demand available nationwide should be implemented. Real educational reform should be implemented on a national level. Real economic reform, not QE, needs to be formulated and implemented by Congress and the executive branch departments that oversee our economy. A jobs bill needs to be enacted into law. We need to invest in our future, rather than cut our present as we have been over the last three years. Most of all, we need to invest in those workers and new graduates that fell victim to the Great Recession and still aren't a part of the workforce. The cost of education needs to be brought down and crushing student debt eliminated.

Personal responsibility is "Conservative-speak" for blame the poor. Birth rates have fallen sharply since 2007. Unless and until we stop investing only in the 1% and start investing in the 99%, inequality will keep widening.

In a real economy, with real investment back, the gap will shrink.

I taught modern literature for some years at the University of Cincinnati and worked for a time with CCM conductor and composer Gerhard Samuels on a libretto for Faulkner's Absalom, Absalom!
Samuels retired before we could get very far, and died not long afterwards. A music student in a Faulkner class of mine had asked if he could work-up an opera for Absalom for his term paper, and I agreed. He felt it was very tough going, but through his exercise, I saw that the kernel story of Absalom -- the half-brothers who discover during the War Between the States that one of them has black blood -- is a magnificent tale and as operatic as a story can be.
This novel is regarded as Faulkner's greatest work. I drafted a libretto of my own, learning from the trials of my student, just because I wanted to imagine how this tale would look and sound on stage. Showed it to Samuels, and he was enthralled by its musical possibilities. It's unlikely, though, to be sure, that we would have succeeded in finding support. If anyone would like to see this draft libretto, please get in touch through lavernetom37@gmail.com. I'd be happy to share it for whatever it might be worth to anyone. We MUST some day be able to see an Absalom on stage!

Weisgall's Esther is deserving of a place. I heard one of its first performances at City Opera, and it is, despite the difficulty of its musical vocabulary, a masterful work, both musically and dramatically.  I am also truly puzzled that one of the finest American operas I have ever heard, Daron Hagen's Shining Brow, has not found the place in the repertoire that it deserves. It blows most contemporary American operas out of the water, truly one of the finest achievements not only in American opera, but in American music.

I often tell my students not to overlook the obvious--advice I feel could have benefited the choices made in this article. I feel that Olivier Messiaen's "Saint François d'Assise," premiered in 1983, was improperly overlooked. It was broadcast live on French television, has been recorded five times (including a DVD), has been published in both orchestral and vocal scores, has been the subject of two monographs and several articles, and has received numerous productions worldwide, despite its considerable challenges to producers, performers, and audiences. Why such success? It's merited by the opera's remarkable musical riches and invaluable messages, made especially relevant today with Pope Francis's attention to poverty and inequality. "Saint François" is the greatest work by a composer whose stature among classical musicians in the late twentieth century is unsurpassed. Thoughtful, open-minded, and open-eared listeners will find this opera far more rewarding than most, if not all, of the operas mentioned in the article or in other comments. Give it a spin!
